I donâ€™t mean to be a Karen (Sorry to the people named Karen, I donâ€™t mean you!), but if anyone wants to complain on how he skipped Spaghetti... Spaghetti is actually American food. Italian immigrants were so poor they couldnâ€™t afford the ingredients required for thick, meaty sauces. When they came to the US, they were wild when they found out that luxuries such as meat was so cheap, and in big amounts, so they bought that and made a pasta that we now know a Spaghetti!

Alcuni tipi di pasta sono molto poco conosciuti anche da noi (e visto che sei italiana capisci quanto sia vasta e diversificata la tradizione della pasta nelle varie regioni d'Italia). Un esempio: le "lorighittas", a forma di due anelli intrecciati, tradizionali del paese di Morgongiori in Sardegna, venivano preparata proprio in occasione dei matrimoni, come simbolo delle fedi nuziali. Anche i "culurgiones", tipici dell'Ogliastra, nel centro-est della Sardegna, possono essere poco noti, anche se dubbito fortemente che negli USA riescano a reperire come ingrediente il "casu-ascedu", un formaggio freschissimo, quasi una cagliata, di latte di pecora preparato col processo di acidificazione.

Â @ireneshelton3661Â  it really depends... as many of you know, Italy is basically divided in two parts: Northern Italy is way more expensive than Southern Italy and It has the best services (we can say that it is the "international" Italy), but if you want to live the "real" Italy (as you foreigners are used to see on TV) Southern Italy is the best.  To answer your question, a single person can live a good life in the suburbs with 1500-1600â‚¬ per month in the North, maybe 200-300â‚¬ less in the South. In general, bench flour means any flour you don't really care about (i.e. protein content, wheat type, etc).  When I'm baking or making pasta or really anything requiring dough, I just take whatever bits of flour I have left on my table and scrape them together, then sift them into a container for my bench flour.  It's a mishmash of a bunch of different kinds of flour for me.  AP flour works just fine as well.  Really it doesn't matter, it's just some flour you use to make things workable.  Personally I wouldn't throw anything weird in there though, whole wheat, rye, etc.
It's just referring to the flour out onto the counter or "bench" while you're working your dough

I'm mesmerized by the sheer ease that he cranks these shapes out with.  As an aside, anyone else keep rolling their eyes at him calling the dinner knife a "butter knife"? It is a "dinner knife" or a regular "table knife" outside America. A butter knife is more of a flattened spoon in shape, and only used in the butter container or crock, or sometimes moonlighting in spreadable cheese on the table.

Â @Albanez39Â  onions and garlic compliment tomato sauce very well

Â @allanhenriques2694Â  Depends on the plate mate. Pomodoro e Basilico is made with onions (just a little); while All' Arrabbiata (alla "angry") is made with garlic (also a small amount).    I personally hate garlic when used in conjunction with tomatoes, except for the Crudaiola which is a cold plate (You don't cook the "seasoning") and uses garlic and cherry tomatoes.     I also prefer some Italian plates in my own way, e.g. using Parmiggiano on Aglio e Olio) and my father goes mad everytime I do that. My issue is that all of these American Youtube chefs are teaching people to cook the wrong recipes. They ought to get a culinary degree in Italian cuisine before they can be able to teach people how to cook...  Ultimately, onions, garlic, parsley, basil etc, are only used in MINIMAL AMOUNTS. They should add something to the flavour of the dish, but not completely overwhelm and mask the other ingredients.   If you want to cook Italian, make sure to watch a video made by an ITALIAN! Even for PIZZA, which is fairly simple to make...yet Americans have achieved to ruin that as well during the decades. The same applies to every cuisine; You want Mexican? Thai? Japanese? Then look for a Youtuber that was born and still lives in this country. Nowadays you can understand everything with auto-translated captions. Take care my friend!

JazzyGemmi Thereâ€™s no such thing. You can find ratios online, but the problem is that the itâ€™ll be different depending on where you live due to the difference in humidity. Besides, part of the fun of pasta making is doing it by feel. Donâ€™t worry too much about exact quantities, if itâ€™s too dry, add some water, if itâ€™s too sticky, add some flour. One thing I will say though is that making semolina dough is a lot harder than making egg dough, so you should start there if this is your first time.

Â @axjkalsok1058Â   Thank you. I have made pasta with egg from regular and wheat flour. That is why I wanted to try it with semolina. Can you tell me which brand to go with? Or what specification to look for while purchasing semolina?

JazzyGemmi The bobâ€™s red mill stuff should be fine. You can always go the extra mile and import some real nice italian stuff, but imo thats not really worth the extra money until youâ€™re more familiar with the process. In terms of specifications, youâ€™re looking for a very fine grain flour. If the flour isnâ€™t ground fine enough, youâ€™ll end up with a sort of sand rather than dough.

This is a wonderfully informative video but it is a myth that pasta came to Italy from China. Unfortunately, there are problems with this theory, least of which is that the noodles they were making in China arenâ€™t technically considered pasta. Polo also described Chinese noodles as being like â€œlaganaâ€, which implies he was possibly already familiar with a pasta-like food before going to China. Further, in 1279, there was a Genoese soldier that listed in the inventory of his estate a basket of dried pasta. Polo didnâ€™t come back from China until 1295. For those who donâ€™t know, Genoa is a sea port in Italy. Further, the modern pasta like we know it was first described in 1154 by an Arab geographer, Idrisi, as being common in Sicily. So Marco Polo could not have brought pasta to Italy via China. It was already in Italy at that time.

19:00 he never said Marco Polo brought pasta to Italy. He said "pasta is originally from China..."  Marco Polo lived in the 13th century. The Silk Road connecting China to the Middle East and Europe was established 130 BC by the Han dynasty to facilitate trade with the West. The same Han dynasty which has the earliest known written record of people eating noodles. Arab traders most likely brought noodles along with everything else they trade with like silk, spices, and paper (the process of which they learned from the Chinese) over a thousand years before Marco Polo was even born.

Â @gaston24uruÂ  "So what would the leading hypotheses for how pasta got to europe be?"  One possibility is that it DIDN'T "get to" Europe, but rather was invented there, and that any similarity to the Chinese counterpart is purely coincidental.
I mean it's not so hard to believe someone came up with the idea to mix egg and flour and boil it.

It did get to Europe after the 12th century through jewish communities (who probably invented the modern way to eat pasta in the west) and arab merchants. Before that there wasn't a tradition of boiling dough in Europe.
Archologists found picutres of noodle/pasta making devices in the graves of etruscan people.

Sergio Robaina It is a normal evolution of mixing water with semolina flour, wheat flour or rice flour. Any civilizations that mix water with flour creates dough that ended in shapes and cooking of any kind of leavened bread, flat bread (injera, naan, pita, pizza), noodles (rice flour), ramen (wheat flour), pasta (semolina flour). Aztecs have their tortillas flat breads of corn flour and water and they never have a pale idea of what a Chinese was, neither Chinese never ever heard of Aztecs. ğŸ˜€ğŸ˜ğŸ˜˜

As I know it the history of Italian pasta dates back to the Etruscan population (we're talking about central Italy, X-I sec BC) and its tradition was later on passed onto Greeks and Romans. The pasta these populations were familiar with was laganon (in Greece, then developed into the modern "lasagna") and makaria (in Etruria, then developed into "maccheroni") and it was a mixture of flour and water. I also heard (but I'm not fully persuaded by this fact) that the first ones to have the intuition of making pastasciutta (literally dried pasta) were people from the middle east back in the Neolithic age and what pushed them was the fact that they didn't have full access to water all year long, being pastasciutta a food that can be stored for quite a long time once dried. Of course the noodle tradition is huge in China as well and is dated back to centuries ago but the process of making noodles is pretty different from that of pasta, that's why the most ancient and direct testimony we have of something similar to modern noodles, that goes back to 3800 years ago in Lajia, China, is considered not linked at all to the Italian pasta. Just wanted to add what I came across doing my researches :)

Camilla Ferretti: Dear Camilla, any populations that in history mixed flour + water in order to make wheat or corn or rice more edibile, sooner or later ended creating dough kneading this flour, and then they tried to cook this dough. Next step was to imagine a way to preserve this dough for more time, for example creating biscuits that last for weeks, cooking with spices like sesame (spiced bread) as long as spices are disgusting for insects and preserve bread from the mold, so again it ends resisting for weeks, or drying the dough and make dried pasta that lasts for months. Etc... Etc... Humans are intelligent beings. Just the fact Europeans had wheat not rice doesn't make them lesser intelligent than Chinese so then Europeans were such that dumb and unable to create dough and then again being uncapable of kneading and cooking it.

Â @silverdawn813Â  The Silk Road was not established "by" the Han Dynasty, but "during." I don't mean to nit-pick, but for those who are learning from your very informative comment may get confused. It's very interesting how certain cultures gain credit for different dishes and applications, but many would be very surprised to learn just about everything on the culinary scene we still enjoy today, actually originated from the Arabs. Even ice-cream, which many falsely believe was "invented" by Italy.
Â @GinaG56883Â  not to nitpick, but the earliest form of ice cream came from China in the form of a milk and rice mixture packed in snow
That might be considered an iced treat of sorts, but sorbet, granita and yes, ice-cream as we know it to be today, really did come from the Arabs!

It is possible (and probable) that different types of cooked dough originated in different places, in this case China and Italy, but I suspect other places in the world too. What is certain tough, is that when noodles managed to make its way from China to Europe, it had been already there for centuries.

Massimo, it's a common myth that Marco Polo brought pasta from China to Italy, however it is possible that pasta did come to Italy from China (possibly via Arabia) much earlier than Marco Polo's time. It's also possible that the two cultures developed similar foods independently of each other.

excellent observation but the combinations are really too many and often change from region to region. to get you an idea, Italian cooking experts have cataloged about 380 types of pasta (in this video you have only seen 27 of them). a small tip that I can give you is that the long pasta has a rule that applies throughout Italy: the thin ones are combined with fish, the medium ones with truffle sauce (strictly butter and truffle nothing else) and meat sauce and broad with sauces of wild boar / other wild animals. I do not want to do the usual proud Italian but the variety of cheeses, meats, sausages etc etc ... is impressive and changes within a few kilometers. For example, I do not know many local specialties near where I live not out of ignorance but because it would be almost impossible

Don't be so scared, fresh pasta is very easy to make. Most of these shapes are made using the same technique, just keep trying. The hard part comes when you cook fresh pasta, you have to be very careful with cooking time and most important be careful with the sauce. Trust me, spend some time training your pasta making skills, it'll worth it.

Jennie Ahn, many types of pasta are also known as "macaroni" in English and "maccheroni" in Italian, but most Americans think only of elbow macaroni when they hear "macaroni." Penne, rigatoni, fusilli, etc. are all "macaroni." (Next time you're at the supermarket, look at the small print on boxes of pasta and see how many say "Enriched Macaroni Product" somewhere on the front of the box.)

It's incredible the similarities that different cultures have :)

Spazik86   Sometimes directions and measurements are required.  I know,..... weird,huh??!!!

Â @Spazik86Â   Yeah and it has to be proportioned to come out correctly. Making dough isn't easy. Obviously not rocket science but it takes practice.......  Like someone else said. Measurements and directions. Duh

Â @Spazik86Â   Plus there are many many recipes. All of which work wonderfully.   Genarro's recipe is one of my favorites. 150g double zero (00) flour + 50g durum wheat semolina + 2 eggs. Mix dry ingredients then add eggs in a shallow bowl or plate and mix with a spoon. Once it starts to come together you transfer to the table or a cutting board and knead it until it forms. If it's too dry, add liquid. Nothing fancy, just water works fine.  Yeah it's not rocket science but it's not an easy thing. It can be messed up with the slightest miscalculation. Each Italian family has a different recipe for their food. It all depends. So I'd dial down that arrogance famğŸ˜‰ğŸ™„

(just a few "errors", like: it's tÃ¨nero, not tenÃ¨ro) I am from Parma, Emilia Romagna, and I was waiting for your cappelletti and anolini. It's important to stress that you gave indications for the filling, but every family will have a different one and very often with meat. There are sort of religous wars about how to call the different forms of pasta. For instance: for all my life I called stuffed pasta in my family "cappelletti" but almost everyone else here calls them "anolini" and I am considered an heretic, wort of flogging or stoning for this sin...  yes, food and pasta are quite important around here...  nice work!

The shape also effects the taste because their geometry plays a crucial role in determining how the sauce sticks to the pasta and whether it can hold filling or not. Actually there is no definitive proof that pasta originated in China and there is some evidence suggesting it did originate in the West. Maybe we should stop just assuming everything in Western culture is unoriginal and everything outside the West is original because it's very untrue and unfair. Pretty much everything is cross cultural and Pasta in Italy is definitely Italian and does not need to give real credit to any other culture for whatever reason. You're not going to hear anyone in China, or anyone outside for that matter, claim that something made there may have originated somewhere else even if there is some truth to it.

lawrence wei Many of "your" pasta is dry (Bucatini, Farfalle, Spaghetti, Macaroni etc) and are industrial products (not always but generally they are). In the video is fresh pasta (Lasagna, Tortellini, Ravioli, Pappardelle, Agnolotti etc) with different doughs; usually depends on region, for example in the north it's frequently used egg pasta while in southern Italy almost always the dough is just flour (or semolina) and water. Gnocchi are still different because are made with potatoes (and little flour). I know it seems strange for a foreigner yet each of these types are right for different sauces (it's not just the taste but also the texture that changes everything). Sry for my "eng", ciao.

I do not think so, you're talking about a dish that has a few hundred years, since the term for Sardinian stuffed pasta comes from the Greek "collyra", so I do not think it derives from the Polish. The dish appears in 1811 in a list of Sardinian dishes. Moreover, Sardinia is an island and in ancient times its people lived for centuries isolated (even the Romans could not completely dominate the island). So it is a dish of a very proud people and linked to its culinary traditions, in a certain sense "closed", which will never put the dish of another nation among his. Your grandma's plate remains good, but nobody has copied anyone. N.B. for your info: from 2015 the "Culurgiones" are an IGP product (protected geographical indication) brand of origin that you can "flaunt" only if you produce it in the place of origin.

HOW DID THIS VIDEO BRING ME TO TEARS!  My family used to drape the noodles over the kitchen chairs, I miss the old traditions of pasta making. My grandpa owned a farm, he grew a lot of the ingredients they used, particularly the meat, while my grandma and aunties would make the sauces and pasta and my uncle would make sausages. Those are the kinds of things you teach and not write down in a recipe book. When my grandpa passed away, cooking in that way, of relying on one another and collaborating on a big Sunday meal, stopped. That's how much this video means to me. Thank you for making it.

That's true, infact the Italians started to making pasta after Marco Polo returned to Italy from China with their noodles.  Basically we replaced the rice flour to durum flour to making our own pasta. PS: I am Italian^^ Cheers

That's untrue, actually. The Italians were eating pasta centuries before Marco Polo even left. Pasta actually spread through Italy from Sicily, which was under Arab occupation in the 9th century. The Arabs had picked up noodlemaking from the Chinese through their extensive trade relations with them, and passed it on to the Sicilians.
Still ultimately from the Chinese, just with an extra step.

Pasta, or paste as the Romans called the dough, was being made in Rome in the 2nd century BCE.  Noodles were talked about in what is now China as early as 300 CE.  It was also found just about everywhere grain was cultivated going back at least 2000 years.  Everyone invented it.
The story about Marco Polo bringing pasta from China is a myth made up by ad agencies in the 20s & 30s.

You can put in a ziplock bag and freeze pretty much all kinds of pasta with fillings and also the more sturdy, consistent shapes like malloreddus or cencioni. As for the more long and thin kinds like tagliatelle or tagliolini I would say it's best to make them and enjoy them in the same day, they don't really hold well in the freezer. Hope it was helpful!
